title: The Antiquary - Complete
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: "But ye wadna wait to hear out my tale, Monkbarns--she gaed out, and shecame in again with the gardener sae sune as she saw that nane o' ye wereclodded ower the Craig, and that Miss Wardour was safe in the chariot;she was hame a quarter of an hour syne, for it's now ganging ten--sairdroukit was she, puir thing, sae I e'en put a glass o' sherry in herwater-gruel."

title: Journal of a tour and residence in Great Britain, during the years 1810 and 1811, by a French traveller :
author: Simond, L.
snippet: The great rocky mass of Salisbury  Craig, close to Edinburgh, presents some appearances certainly less inex[)licable by the Muttonian theory than by any other.

title: Four years in the Old world;
author: Palmer, Phoebe
snippet: It is a rocky height, cloven in the midst by two valleys, separating the eastern portion with its lion-shaped summit, from the western, known as Craig's.

title: Sketches of continental Europe and Great Britain.
author: Newell, William Whiting
snippet: Just beyond the Palace are Salisbury Craig and Arthur's Seat.

title: Sketches of continental Europe and Great Britain.
author: Newell, William Whiting
snippet: PasSing  the old residence of Hugh Miller and Jennie Deans, Salisbury Craig and Arthurs's Seat, we reached our quarters in Prince street, too happy to rest.

title: Tweed and Don; or, Recollections and reflections of an angler for the last fifty years ...

snippet: For trout, it may be tried above the Iron Bridge, at Craig- ellachie^ when the water is in good condition only.

title: Tweed and Don; or, Recollections and reflections of an angler for the last fifty years ...

snippet: Those who are in this quarter, whether fishing or otherwise, should stop a while at Craig- ellachie.

title: Lady Jean's Son. A novel
author: Tytler, Sarah
snippet: The affairs of Edinburgh didnot engross the speakers, though they were readyenough to discuss them in passing—how the firststone of the first house of the new town had justbeen laid by Craig the builder; and how thefamous aloe, which was seventy years old, wasabout to blossom in the Physic Gardens.

title: Sparks from a Locomotive; or Life and Liberty in Europe. By the author of “Belle Brittan's Letters.” [The dedication signed, H. F., i.e. H. Fuller.]

snippet: The fifty-guinea prize poem, which was read atthe Crystal Palace celebration 'in London, is theproduction of Miss Isa Craig, a native of Edinburg.
